text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Abantu bali, abalishiba kwati tabakwata amano yabafyashi ababapeleka. Kuli chalo ichi, nshimfye ukuti pa BECE, mabungelo yamenshi yapangwa na Ghana Education Service. Kwa mfano, ukuchagua ba supervisor na invigilators, kwapangwa na district exams officer, alitontonkanya. Maukali ake yabafumine mu kufumya kwa JoyNews Hotline investigation ilipangwa na GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, ilipangwa ukwabula ukwabula wa kushikana kwa mafunde ku masandaulo ya mafunde.]
backtranslated: [People were, who felt like they had no parental sense to deliver them. For this country, I have to say that at BECE, the water levels are set by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and vigilantes, is set by the district exams officer, he thought. His anger stemmed from the publication of a JoyNews Hotline investigation by GH Probes Francisca Enchil, which was conducted without any legal interference from law enforcement agencies.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.
translated: [Ndala zinga za kuchita na za utamaduni zilichitika kuwa vikwazo vikuu vya kupata na kutumia MHCS. Zaidi ya nusu ya wanawake waliochunguzwa walitaja umaskini, ujuzi usio na elimu, vikwazo kutoka kwa mume, umbali wa vituo vya afya, na mizunguko ndefu kama sababu za kutotumia huduma. Zaidi ya hayo, zaidi ya theluthi moja ya wanawake walitaja mazoea ya kitamaduni ndani ya jamii zao kuwa sababu ya kupunguza kwa muda wa kutafuta huduma. Matokeo haya yanaonyesha kwamba kushughulikia afya ya uzazi katika eneo hili kunahitaji zaidi ya kuboresha tu huduma za kimatibabu; pia inamaanisha kushughulikia changamoto za kijamii na za kibinafsi zilizo na mizizi kwa kina ambazo wanawake hukabiliana nazo kila siku.]
backtranslated: [A number of social and cultural factors were found to be major barriers to the availability and use of MHCS. More than half of the women surveyed cited poverty, lack of education, difficulties with menstruation, distance from health facilities, and long cycles as reasons for not using the services. Additionally, more than one-third of the women cited cultural practices within their communities as a reason for the reduced time to seek care. These results suggest that addressing reproductive health in this area requires more than just improving medical services; it also means addressing the social and personal and root causes of the challenges women face every day.]

text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.
translated: [Pa shupitilo lwe, Unoka alile mwimbashi wapwa. text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Pa Derby Avenue RC Basic School na St. George’s Anglican Basic School mu Accra, abamisheli bali kubomfya bapasha GH¢60 kila siku, abasamula bali kubomfya mifuko ya GH¢400, na abantu bali kubomfya kuchelela kwa Aseda Offertory. John Kapi alisambisha kwati uku WAEC itampa foni kwa mizani iyi, ni wajibu wa Ghana Education Service (GES) kuchukua kuchita kwa maana. Na kwa hiyo, uku mizani iyi ikafika, uku foni ikafika kwa bo, tuna [WAEC] tuchite kwati bali kuchita vyema na kuchita kwa maana kwa abantu.]
backtranslated: [At Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George's Anglican Basic School in Accra, missionaries used GH¢60 daily, porters used GH¢400 bags, and people used Aseda Offertory's free lunch. John Kapi taught that when the WAEC calls for these scales, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take reasonable action. And therefore, when the scales arrive, when the call comes to them, let [WAEC] act as if they were taking reasonable action and the people's reasonable action.]

text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.
translated: [Ku mitundu ya kubepa mu Ghana, haswa mu masomo ya Kumbungu, kupata na kutumya mafunso ya bafyashi (MHCS) yalikwata amabala. Ichitundu ichi chikwata ku chita amabala yonse yaliyopa kubana abakashi kutumya mafunso yonse na kufikulwa ubwino wa mafunso yaliyopwa. Uchunguzi ulitumya njia ya kuchanganya, ichitambulisha data ya kubwata na ya kubwata kufikwa kwa mafunso yonse ya kufikwa. Njia ya kuchanganya ichi chikwata ku chita abakashi 441 abali bafyashi na abakashi ba kubepa na kufikwa na abafyashi 20. Ichitundu ichi chikwata ku chita mafunso yaliyopa kubana abakashi kutumya mafunso yonse na kufikwa ubwino wa mafunso yaliyopwa.]
backtranslated: [For the types of fraud in Ghana, especially in Kumbungu trials, the Mental Health and Submission Questionnaire (MHCS) has fields. This article covers all fields related to women's submission of all questionnaires and the quality of the completed questionnaires. The survey sends a combined total of 441 women who were parents and 20 women who were false parents. This combined total covers all fields related to women's submission of all questionnaires and the quality of the completed questionnaires.]

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.
translated: [Okonkwo alikwata amano kubwa sana mu villages yake tisa na kufikisha kubwa sana, amano yaliyobanwa kabisa kwenye mafanikio yake yaliyo kubwa sana. Alikuwa na umri wa miaka kumi na nane tu, alileta utukufu kwenye kijiji chake kwa kumshinda Amalinze Mnyama, mshindani mashuhuri ambaye hakuwa ameshindwa kwa miaka saba. Amalinze alipata jina lake la utani kwa sababu mgongo wake haukutikisa dunia hata mara moja. Wazee wa kijiji walichukulia ushindi wa Okonkwo kuwa moja ya mapigano makali zaidi waliziona.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo had the greatest talent in his nine villages and the greatest achievement, a talent that was fully reflected in his great successes. He was only eighteen years old, he brought glory to his village by defeating Amalinze Mnyama, a famous champion who had not been defeated for seven years. Amalinze hated his nickname because his back shook the world so much. The village elder considered Okonkwo's victory one of the most fierce battles he had ever seen.]

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka alimfumya kamati kwamba atawapa usaidizi kamili wa usimamizi na sekretarieti kutoka kwa Wizara na akawatia moyo kuungana na mashirika ya kiraia, washirika wa maendeleo, na taasisi za kidini katika kufanya kazi yao. Alielezea kazi hiyo kuwa nzuri lakini ya heshima, akisisitiza kwamba watu wa Gbenyiri na jamii zinazozunguka walikuwa wakimtazama kamati kama zana za amani, upatanisho, na uponyaji.]
backtranslated: [The Minister directed the committee to provide full administrative and secretarial support from the Ministry and to encourage them to join civil society organizations, development agencies, and religious institutions in carrying out their work. He described the work as beautiful but dignified, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking forward to the committee's hundred years of peace, reconciliation, and healing.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.
translated: [Ndimo tafika pali pali icalo kuonesha mizani ya masiku yalikwata amano yaku kufupisha ubungulushi wa bukali. Kali kwasu ilikuwa ukosefu wa bafyashi, ukosefu uwa bafyashi ukali pali pali icalo kupeleka kuwa na mizani ya masiku yalikwata amano. Pali pali icalo, ukosefu wa vifaa na madwala yalikuwa ndalama kubwa. Kwa mfano, abafupi ba kufupisha bukali balipanga ukali pali pali icalo kuwa na bafyashi abafupi na kufupisha vifaa vya bukali kama vile vifaa vya kufupisha bukali na vifaa vya kufupisha bukali vya kufupisha bukali.]
backtranslated: [It is not enough for the world to show the scale of the days of wisdom to reduce the effects of anger. The past was a lack of parents, the lack of parents will cause the world to fall and the scale of the days of wisdom to fall. For the world, the lack of equipment and illnesses were a great cost. For example, the short-term anger makers have created the scale of the days of wisdom to reduce the effects of anger and the short-term anger makers have created the scale of the days of anger and the short-term anger makers.]

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.
translated: [Okonkwo alikwata amano, aliyelelewa na mkubwa sana na uso wa kutisha, ni matokeo ya mabega yake ya nywele na pua pana. Kupumua kwake kilikuwa kivyo kizito kwamba familia yake ilikuwa inasikia kutoka kwenye nyumba zao wakati alipokuwa amelala. Wakati alipokuwa akitembea, viatu vyake havikuwa vikigusa ardhini, na kumfanya kuonekana kama anayekusanyika kumpiga mtu—jambo ambalo alilifanya mara nyingi. Alikuwa na kikohozi kidogo, na katika nyakati za hasira, alikwenda kwenye mikono yake wakati maneno yalimkosea. Hakuna subira kwa wanaume ambao hawakuwa wenye mafanikio, na hisia hii ilianza kutokana na aibu yake ya kina kwa ajili ya baba yake.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo had a very intelligent, grown-up and very large face, a result of his shoulder hair and a wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their rooms while he slept. When he walked, his shoes would not touch the ground, making him look like he was collecting dust which he had often done. He had a slight cough, and in moments of anger, he would walk away with his hands when words offended him. There was no patience for men who were not his own, and this feeling was due to his shameful disdain for those who had been his successes.]

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.
translated: [Imiti ikalamba kwa kuyeleka, kwa mabemba kuibuka na fule kuimba. Amalinze alikuwa mwipikaji, lakini Okonkwo alikuwa mwipikaji pia, na mwangalifu kama samaki kwenye maji. Wanaume wawili walikuwa wenye nguvu sana, misuli na neva zao zikiyumba kufikia kwenye kufungwa. Lakini mwishowe, Okonkwo akatoka mshindi. Usindi huu mkubwa ulikuwa tu mwanzo wa urithi wake. Kwa miaka ishirini iliyofuata, sifa yake ilisambaa kama moto wa pori, uliochochewa na azimio lake lisilobadilika na ushindi wa kibinafsi.]
backtranslated: [The trees grow tall, the waves rise and the dust sings. The wind was the cook, but Okonkwo was also the cook, as careful as a fish in the water. The two men were very strong, their muscles and nerves twisted to the point of being trapped. But in the end, Okonkwo won the victory. This great victory was only the beginning of his legacy. For the next twenty years, his reputation spread like wildfire, fueled by his unwavering determination and personal triumph.]

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.
translated: [Komitee ya kusuluhisha yenye wanachama saba itaongozwa na Bw. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Wanachama wengine wa kamati hii ni Alhaji Collins Dauda (MB na mwenyekiti wa Kamati ya Ardhi na Rasilimali asilia katika Bunge), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Mwenyekiti wa Baraza la Amani la Mkoa wa Savannah), Dkt. Festus Aubyn (Mtandao wa Kusuluhisha Migogoro wa Afrika Magharibi), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Mkurugenzi wa Wanawake, Vijana, Amani na Usalama wa Taasisi, Kituo cha Mafunzo ya Amani cha Kimataifa cha Kofi Annan), Profesa Ramatu Alhassan na Dkt. George Amoh (Katibu Mkuu wa NPC) ambaye atakuwa katibu.]
backtranslated: [The seven-member mediation committee is chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. The other members of this committee are Alhaji Collins Dauda (MB and chairman of the Ardhi and Rasilimali Committee in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chairman of the Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West African Network for Conflict Resolution), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of the Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peace Education Center), Professor Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (NPC Secretary General) who will be the chairperson.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
translated: [Unoka, tata wa Okonkwo, alishapita dunia miaka kumi iliyopita. Yeye alikuwa mtu aliyejulikana kwa uvivu wake na kutojali, akiishi tu kwa sasa bila kufikiria kuhusu siku zijazo. Kila pesa alizoweza kupata—jambo ambalo halikuwa la kawaida—alitumia mara moja kwenye mvinyo wa mchikichi, akikusanya majirani wake kwa ajili ya sherehe. Aliamini kwamba kuona mdomo wa mtu aliyekufa ni kuona ujinga wa kuto kula kilicho nacho maishani. Unoka pia alikuwa na deni kubwa, akiwa na deni kwa karibu kila mmoja wa majirani wake.]
backtranslated: [Snake, Okonkwo's father, passed away ten years ago. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present without thinking about the future. Every penny he could find to earn was used immediately for the unusual word mchikichi wine, gathering his neighbors for a feast. He believed that seeing the mouth of a dead person was the best way to eat something pure in life. Snake was also deeply in debt, owing money to almost every one of his neighbors.]
